nodes.bodyText: This effectively is a new module, so you should probably rename it to fabric-biome-api-v1

-version = getSubprojectVersion(project, "1.0.2")
+version = getSubprojectVersion(project, "1.1.0")

nodes.bodyText:
Is it? It removes one public method and otherwise changes Biome arguments to RegistryKey?
Granted. that is a breaking change but does that justify changing the module?

nodes.bodyText:
The entire module is effectively detached from every older version of biome api. Plus these are breaking changes with a module that was never re-released with .2.
The other biomes PR has the consensus by modmuss that naming and packages should be adapted due to an effective full break.

nodes.bodyText: I would suggest using InternalBiomeUtils.fromRawId similar to InternalBiomeUtils.getRawId so we can make them both use a DynamicRegistryManager if needed
Vanilla still uses Biomes.fromRawId itself in a place where a DynamicRegistryManager is unavailable, so this won't help.

You mean BiomeLayer.sample? I would've changed that too.
Dunno, to me that would feel better.

I would suggest capturing the biomeRegistry in VanillaLayeredBiomeSource.<init> and use that one theoughout for the conversion RegistryKey <-> RawId. That should be compatible with using the DynamicRegistryManager then (and I think also json biomes).
We'd have to check if that capture covers all use cases, but I think it does.
This will still not fix the Vanilla logic that also accesses the raw-id mapping directly and thus just complicates the logic needlessly.

This validation doesn't seem great to me. How does this interact with registering to DynamicRegistryManager.BUILTIN or using json biomes?
I'd suggest dropping this validation for the initial PR.
This seems like it could cause issues, and that's the last thing we want validation to do.

It doesn't interact with it. This API will be used by modders in their Mod initializers, when no dynamic registry manager exists. The only way to ensure only properly registered Biomes are used is to validate against the BuiltInRegistries, and follow the same general approach Vanilla does.
I would suggest using InternalBiomeUtils.fromRawId similar to InternalBiomeUtils.getRawId so we can make them both use a DynamicRegistryManager if needed.
Answered above.
I would suggest using InternalBiomeUtils.fromRawId similar to InternalBiomeUtils.getRawId so we can make them both use a DynamicRegistryManager if needed.
Answered above.
I would suggest using InternalBiomeUtils.fromRawId similar to InternalBiomeUtils.getRawId so we can make them both use a DynamicRegistryManager if needed.
Answered above.
I would suggest... Ok, I think you get the point.
Answered above.
Same thing again.
Answered above.
Just gonna mention that I like my approach in my fork better, but this is probably fine too.
That might actually be better. I'll investigate adopting that approach.
Adopted your approach
I know you disagree, but I'm still gonna comment that I don't think we should use BuiltinRegistries, but DynamicRegistryManager.BUILTIN. We can easily provide a getter for that registry too.
Paired with #1052 this is the easiest to explain and safest approach of registering worldgen objects, since it is also very easy to follow through the code (and check against Vanilla's behavior)

Would be nice if we could get this to work using json biomes, even if you think we shouldn't use those.
Putting this here cause it'd be part of the test mod.

I don't think defining the same thing you could define with a constructor call in a JSON file justifies the added complexity for this API and everyone else involved. There is literally nothing else you gain from doing it in a JSON file.
Datapacks don't factor into this. You can still override biome definitions from data packs like you can with Vanilla biomes, and defining a new biome in a datapack ist pointless since the mod that calls this API could not know about it beforehand.

What version did this biome thing occur in?
.2 is probably not optimistic enough about version ranges, but not a major deal tbf
